author: Randy DeSoto
title: Ryan Finds Ally In Steve Bannon For His Proposed Border Fee
text:
Ryan Finds Ally In Steve Bannon For His Proposed Border Fee “It’ll actually benefit consumers ..." by Randy DeSoto February 28, 2017 at 5:02pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
House Speaker Paul Ryan has found an ally in White House chief strategist Steve Bannon for a key aspect of his proposed tax reforms. 
As a means of paying for a corporate tax cut, Ryan is calling for a border adjustment tax for any goods produced overseas and sold in the United States. 
Ryan’s plan has several backers in the Trump administration, “including Stephen Miller, a senior Trump policy aide; Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, a longtime Ryan ally; newly confirmed Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross; and trade adviser Peter Navarro, according to a senior administration official. Jared Kushner, a senior adviser and Trump’s son-in-law, is said to be open to the proposal but hasn’t made up his mind,” Bloomberg reported. Advertisement - story continues below 
— Bloomberg Politics (@bpolitics) February 28, 2017 
National Economic Council director Gary Cohn and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin are against the tax. 
Supporters of a border adjustment fee contend it would end the incentive companies have to move their profits overseas to their subsidiaries. Advertisement - story continues below 
One means companies do this is by selling goods and services to their overseas subsidiaries at a reduced price and then buying other goods and services back at a higher price. 
Thereby, companies minimize their U.S. profits , which are taxed at a 35 percent corporate rate — the highest in the world– and maximize their profits in their overseas subsidiaries at the lower tax rate. 
The border adjustment fee, coupled with lowering the corporate tax rate to 20 percent (which Ryan has called for) would take away this incentive. 
Retail companies — like Walmart and Nike — who import many of the products they sell oppose the proposed border adjustment fee because they believe it will affect their bottom line by forcing them to raise their prices. Advertisement - story continues below
